author: SteveL-MSFT
body:
Per [documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_commonparameters?view=powershell-7.1#whatif), `-WhatIf` should describe the effect of the command instead of executing.  So in the case that the file doesn't exist, it shouldn't matter.

## Steps to reproduce

```powershell
Copy-Item ./foo.bar -Destination test -WhatIf
```

## Expected behavior

```none
What If: Performing operation 'Copy File' on
Target './foo.bar'
```

## Actual behavior

```none
Copy-Item: Cannot find path 'foo.bar' because it does not exist.
```

comments.body: `-WhatIf` isn't an _abstract_ hypothetical; its purpose is to test-drive a _specific_ command, so I think it is appropriate to perform as much (side effect-free) up-front validation as possible - in other words: I think the current behavior is correct.

title: Copy-Item -WhatIf should not fail
